reviewText: The last of Disney's "anthology" films, released just before the 2nd Golden Age of Disney animation kicked off (this one was released just before CINDERELLA), is a slightly disjointed film held together by an extremely weak premise...and yet, so many nice moments appear in both parts of the film, that it holds up together very well.The premise of the film was also its original title: TWO FABULOUS CHARACTERS.  Basically, choose two great characters from literature (one British, one American), find two distinctive voices to tell their stories (Basil Rathbone and Bing Crosby), and create some sort of "link" (in this case, a library full of books) to give them a reason to be in the same film.Both halves operate quite independently of each other.  The MR. TOAD section is a nice retelling of some of THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS (it leaves out quite a bit from Kenneth Grahme's original story), with great voice acting and attention to detail.  The animation is nicely done, and the characterizations are first-rate.Highlights include the "Nowhere in Particular" song, Toad's trial, and the battle for Toad Hall.  In addition, gags aplenty appear throughout the film (when Toad doesn't want to listen to his bossy friends, he puts his hands over his ears--the soundtrack suddenly can't hear them either), and much fun is had with the character of the trial lawyer.  The characters had enough popularity to earn themselves an attraction at Disneyland.The 2nd half of the film is SO different from the first that one is first thrown off a bit by Bing Crosby's laid back style.  He even calls Ichabod Crane "old Icky" a few times.  But once one gets used to it, it's hard to imagine anyone else telling the story of THE LEGEND OF SLEEPY HOLLOW.  The animation is top notch here, and the character design of our hero (and his nemesis) are top of the line.  Katrina looks a bit too much like other Disney girls of the era (she is identical to gals from MELODY TIME, MAKE MINE MUSIC, and several short subject), but it's not a distraction.The highlight of the second half is obvious, as it starts with Brom Bones singing the tale of the Headless Horseman to a bunch of partygoers on Halloween night.  Both Crane and Bones are in love with Katrina, and the more brutish Bones is tired of being bested by the wily Crane.  Knowing Crane's superstition, he tells the story to frighten him off.Crane's ride home, and the ensuing chase by the Horseman, are stellar examples of Disney artists at their best.  Thrillingly animated, well scored, with a great blend of sound effects, it is at once spooky and hilarious.  The animators pulled all the stops out with this one, and it shows.Other features on the DVD play up the Halloween aspect of the film (even leaving Mr. Toad and company off the cover altogether), which is fine, and the extras are nice for a family Halloween party.  BUT, the film is much more than a scary treat.Two fabulous characters, whose stories are told by two stellar narrators, brought to life by the amazing artisans at Disney, operating at their peak.  What more could one ask for?

reviewText: This fine feature film, made from two featurettes, is a real gem to add to your collection of family Halloween favorites, or a joy to behold at any time of year.This 11th addition to the Disney feature film canon is worth watching over and over again.In the first featurette, we are treated to a retelling of one story from Kenneth Grahame's "The Wind in the Willows" - the story of what happens when Mr. Toad decides to go for a wild ride in his new motorcar.  I can't even imagine any other version of the vision of Toad Hall and its inhabitants than this one anymore.  I thought it was fairly true to the original source material.  Basil Rathbone provides the narration, but other characters have their own voices.  The only problem with this is that I thought Rathbone's horror talents would have lent themselves better to "Sleepy Hollow".In the second, and far better, story, we are treated to a Disney version of Washington Irving's "Legend of Sleepy Hollow".  While not as scary as the original story, nor anywhere near as scary as Tim Burton's movie based on the same story, it's still chilling enough to make a great Halloween party event without scaring the young ones silly.  The Disney style lends itself fairly well to this story, too, especially in the characterization of Ichabod Crane and other characters.  The story is told by Bing Crosby - who also supplies all of the character voices and songs.  Crosby does a great job on characters who I thought would have been better voiced by Rathbone.The DVD also features a karaoke segment - a standard feature of almost all newer Disney DVDs, as well as a storybook adventure and a gallery of collectibles.A stellar addition to the Disney collection, and a good investment for anyone planning a Halloween get together for children.
summary: Two for the price of one

reviewText: It's strange to see 2 shorts so different and opposing yet fit so well. You know something still resonates with you where you can almost actually nail the timing of it from the dialogue to the songs and specific scenes. Watching both brought back quite a bit of memories and both were still entertaining in their own rights without that kind of aged quality. They were fun and scary at age 6 and they're fun now as well. The only thing I wish was different was the transfer. It's almost like Disney didn't even bother to clean this up like they just slapped on the negative and left it. You get colored dots, specks of dusts and scratches and the image as that flickering quality you might've seen on VHS.The Wind in the Willows, based on the book by Kenneth Grahame and narrated by Basil Rathbone, follows Mr. Toad, an incredibly impulsive character prone to overspending and just as much in fees who gets into so-called "manias". He spots a motorcar one day and is obsessed to the point where he's framed and thrown in jail. With help from his friends MacBadger, Moley and Rat, he has to get his deed back and prove his innocence. The short is funny and even a bit touching in a couple of places.The Legend of Sleepy Hollow, based on the story by Washington Irving and narrated by Bing Crosby, has Ichabod coming to the town of Sleepy Hollow and becomes a school teacher. He falls instantly smitten with Katrina and tries to gain her favor from the brutish, pre-Gaston resident Brom Bones. Brom, to get even with him, tells him the story of the Headless Horseman, a black rider who rides the woods one night a year in search of a head. Even with the controversy they get from parents, Disney can do some pretty heavy scenes, as evidenced by Bambi's mother, the Black Cauldron or the meteor hit from the recent Dinosaur. Add to that is Ichabod's travel through the woods which is an excellent study in sound and imagery to creep you out. Even in older years, it still is an effective scene and most likely the highlight of the whole disc.This seriously needs a remaster, not simply because of the transfer but also since you get the feeling both stories deserve a better look.
summary: One hilarious short and a great spooky one

reviewText: I had never seen these two shorts in their entirety before, since they were only available seperately on VHS when I was little.  I remember loving them both, so I went out in search of this DVD.  Well, it was quite a long search (this thing is impossible to find in stores!), but let me tell you, it was more than a worthwhile journey.In fact, I'd go so far as saying that THE ADVENTURES OF ICHABOD & MR. TOAD is one of the very best animated films Disney has ever done!  It's certainly on my top five.I mean, this movie is the very best example of why exactly Disney was the K-I-N-G back in the day.  It has everything that ever made Disney so masterful!  But rather than continue to pile on the vague praise, I'm gonna tell you just why this movie is so great.The thing that struck me most about this movie after not seeing either segment for years and years, is the quality of the characters and the humor.  By this, I especially mean the subtlety of it all.  There are things in here that only teens and adults could truly appreciate, like the animation.  The movements/facial expressions solidify Disney in their prime, and the song lyrics are witty and clever.  As for the humor, well, I was on the verge of rolling on the floor.  Take for instance, the courtroom scene in the "Mr. Toad" segment.  The lawyer who questions Ratty, Moley, Badger etc. is a glorious character, despite him being on screen for all of three minutes.  His exclamations of ". . . then HOW DID HE GET THE MOTOR CAR?!" and "THAT IS ALL, THANK YOU!!" are hysterical.Moving on to the second segment, the "Disneyfication" of the Legend of Sleepy Hollow, I first of all must comment on the late great Bing Crosby's charming narration/singing.  This film, believe it or not, was actually my first introducion to how great Bing really was, and got me interested in his work.  Anyway, I must say that though Ichabod Crane is the intended protagonist, Brom Bones is DEFINITELY the hero of the story.  He is so awesome!!!  Buying beer for all the guys, and trying to court the fair Katrina. . . . . he's just a great guy!  In fact, Ichabod comes of as a bit of a jerk, but by that I don't mean that his character is any less enjoyable.  This short has classic Disney humor, as well.  For perhaps the greatest example of Disney slapstick ever captured on film, check out the scene where Brom and Ichabod are competing over Katrina's affection whilst carrying groceries for her to her house.  One of the flat-out finnuest scenes I've ever witnessed!On a final note, yet another thing I love about this film is how it's a perfect example of how Disney wasn't all "edited for children" back then.  Modern Disney is for the most part purely kiddie fare, which will make anyone over the age of 8 groan in agony.  I mean, in ICHABOD & MR. TOAD, you see people smoking, drinking, and almost getting their heads cut off with a huge axe!!  Thus, this movie (as well as all of Disney's best work ever) works as an actual MOVIE, which is in itself a major case of superiority over modern Disney animated films.I'm surprised at how the majority of the reviewers here prefer the latter part of the movie.  However, for my favorite I'd have to go with "Mr. Toad," just because I love all its subteties that "Ichabod" lacks slightly.  But both are bonafide classics, and make THE ADVENTURES OF ICHABOD & MR. TOAD a must-have on anyone's DVD shelf.
summary: One of Disney's Most Unsung Works of Art!

reviewText: Generally underrated, or at least relatively overlooked, The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad is a favorite of mine that just keeps getting better with each viewing.  I've seen it probably ten times over the years, yet I keep noticing subtle visual jokes and layers of meaning that I previously missed.  For just one example, only on this last viewing did I finally notice the weasel sleeping in Toad Hall who is supported by a woman in a painting.  My appreciation of the beautiful animation in general also seems to grow with each viewing.The film consists of two halves, the first a Disneyfied version of Kenneth Grahame's "Wind in the Willows", the second a Disneyfied version of Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow".  While both can be read as light, often surreal, sometimes goofy, and always-funny stories (and hence kids, young and old--time for me to raise my hand--can appreciate them), adults can easily read various "deeper" meanings into the tales.For example, Mr. Toad's fickle manias and the predicament they lead to could be seen as a criticism of consumerism.  The Legend of Sleepy Hollow could be read as an exemplification of the value of Taoist or Zen-Buddhist mindfulness and "going with the flow"--as well as a warning about letting delusions take hold instead.  This isn't to say that these interpretations were intended by Grahame, Irving, or Disney's artists, or that they're the "right" interpretations, just that they're made possible and plausible by the depth of the material.

reviewText: The Adventures Of Ichabod and Mr. Toad falls in the line of quality animation by Disney through the 1940s, even though the budgets were considerably smaller than the big ones such as Bambi. Containing an adaptation of The Wind in the Willows and a retelling of the Sleepy Hollow story, this feature is one of my favorite Disney features and is a definite around Halloween. For all that is worth, this still remains one of the most underrated and obscure of Disney's animated classics. This is evident because it did not receive the DVD treatment like some of Disney's more popular titles, but fortunately Disney has given a fairly nice release with this version.First is the story of J. Thaddeus Toad, of Toad Hall. Mr. Toad develops a mania for motor cars, much to the dismay of his friends Moley, Mr. Rat and MacBadger. Toad is framed for stealing a motor car, so it is up to the 4 to clear Toad's good name. Though more overlooked than Ichabod, it is a fun adventure. Featuring good animation and the Disney magic we recognize, this excerpt from The Wind in the Willows is brought to life in memorable fashion.Next is the retelling of The Legend of Sleepy Hollow. Schoolmaster Ichabod Crane is new to Sleepy Hollow, and instantly becomes a popular fellow to the envy of Brom Bones. The two vie for the lovely Katrina, the governor's daughter, with Ichabod upstaging Brom in every way. After hearing the tale of the Headless Horseman, Ichabod embarks on a spooky journey home, constantly looking over his shoulder for the Horseman himself. This one is a must for Halloween. Most adults will probably find this still charming, while it isn't too scary for the children. Overall it is an excellent 1/2 to the feature that I highly recommend.The extras on this disk are scarce, but that is to be expected with a hidden gem among other hugely popular movies. There is a DVD storybook, Singalong song and the classic short "Lonesome Ghosts" featuring Mickey Donald and Goofy as ghost-busters from the Ajax company sent to a haunted house to get rid of ghosts. There is also a game, Mr. Toad's Wild Ride. Here is another treat that may not be obvious. Play the game and get all the answers right to unlock the classic short "Susie the Little Blue Coupe", a fitting extra to go along with Toad's Wild Ride.The sound and picture quality are pretty good, though not to a restored state like say "The Lion King" or "Beauty and the Beast". A charming feature with a few nice extras make this a nice DVD to own for any Disney or animation enthusiast.

reviewText: Have you ever ridden on the Mr Toad ride at Disneyland and wondered where the idea came from? This is it. This is probably the least remembered of the Disney Classic animated features. He does eventually triumph as with all good Disney films. The part about the wild motor car ride that resulted in the popular Disneyland attraction is actually a rather small part of the story. Still, it was fun to watch this little remembered classic.The Adventures of Ichabod features a mild mannered school teacher who falls in love with a beautiful farmer's daughter, but runs afoul of her suitor. The big nasty challenger might have been the inspiration for the nasty suitor in Beauty and the Beast. The climax of the story involves a spooky forest and an encounter with a headless horseman. Will Ichabod escape? You'll have to see the movie.

reviewText: Many are familiar with Disney's cartoon version of Washington Irving's _Legend of Sleepy Hollow_ from its inclusion in two early 1980s Hallowe'en compilations for TV. reviewText: "The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad" is a wonderful collection of two classic tales about two of literature's most unlikeable likeable characters.  Clocking in at just over an hour, this film spends the first thirty or so minutes telling us the story of one J. Thaddeus Toad and his "mania" with motorcars that lands him in the big house.  His friends Badger, Rat, and Mole join together to try and prove his innocence.  In the second half of this film, we see Ichabod Crane trying to make a move on the lovely Katrina Van Tassel.  Eventually he has a run-in with a local legend, the Headless Horeseman.The two "heroes" of these tales aren't your typical lead characters.  Mr. Toad lives a wild, carefree life in which he spends himself into bankruptcy over "manias" that he pursues.  Ichabod Crane is after Katrina not just for her good looks, but for her dad's fat wallet.  Somehow these two antiheroes make you pull for them in both of these tales.The DVD transfer is good considering the source material.  The audio is excellent, and Basil Rathbone and Bing Crosby sound charming as they tell their respective tales.  There is some grain on the film throughout most of the movie, but this is passable.  The music is fun and I'm sure that this flick will hold the attention of any youngster and most adults.Included on the disc are the short "Lonesome Ghosts" featuring Mickey Mouse, Goofy and Donald Duck.  There's also a few previews.  For those who take the time to play "Mr. Toad's Wild Ride" trivia game there's an extra cartoon short, "Susie The Little Blue Coupe."Overall, this is one gem of a film that no true Disney fan should be without.  With Halloween having just passed, this would have been an excellent show to let children watch on that holiday.  It's great fun to watch any time of the year.Highly recommended.
summary: You Might Just Lose Your Head!

reviewText: I recently reviewed "Fun and Fancy Free," released just two years before this film.  Walt Disney tried the same thing in that film that he did in this film; he combined two shorts into one release.  Unfortunately, the technique did not work well in "Fun and Fancy Free."  The technique worked very well in this feature.The first story is that of Mr. Toad, which is a story adapted from "The Wind in the Willows."  J. Thaddeus Toad is quite a fellow.  Mr. Toad likes to follow the whim of the moment, and his friends have a hard time trying to keep him out of trouble.  Mr. Toad is in a pickle this time.  The police found Mr. Toad in a stolen car and shortly he is in prison.  Weasels take over Toad Hall and Mr. Toad can do nothing about it; or can he?  Soon Mr. Toad and his friends are on the run from the law, but they are trying to recover the deed to Toad Hall and clear the name of Mr. Toad in a funny and exciting adventure.The second story is even better than the first.  Ichabod is Ichabod Crane from the story "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow."  Narrated by Bing Crosby, this story is funny and nicely plotted.  The story of Sleepy Hollow is nicely animated and interpreted.  If you saw the wonderful version with Johnny Depp, try this one for a fun comparison.Disney had an instant classic with this 1949 release.  The two stories in this release work well, and are among some of the best animation that Disney has ever done.  These stories are Halloween favorites and are worth watching again and again.  This feature should entertain all but the youngest family members, who may be frightened by some images in the story of Ichabod.  This DVD should be in every family's movie library.Enjoy!

reviewText: ...as one can clearly see when viewing this delightful and very exciting animated "double feature" released by the studio in 1949."The Adventures of Ichabod & Mr. Toad" is truly Disney's greatest animated effort right after the incomparable "Alice in Wonderland".  The stories "Wind in the Willows" and "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" have become not just American literary classics, but also American classics...period.Certainly any child over the age of 5 (possibly even younger than that) knows the story of Mr. Toad, his woodland companions Ratty, Moley & MacBadger, and their many adventures together.  And who could ever forget Ichabod Crane's midnight ride through the haunted forest and his fateful encounter with the Headless Horseman.Both stories are brought to vivid life in this wonderful and timeless film, particularly Washington Irving's "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow".  This version of Irving's classic tale is so much better than Tim Burton's recent remake, mainly because this one is actually based on the original story, and not simply inspired by it.  That's the big problem I have with Burton's version, it doesn't even begin to resemble Irving's original story.  Sure Burton got the setting and a few of the character's names right, but that's it!  Trust me, you'll only be doing yourself a favor by watching this "true to the story" adaption.The narrations of both these stories, done by Basil Rathbone and the late great Bing Crosby, only help to strengthen the ties that bind this animated classic together.  The songs are highly enjoyable, too.  Wish Disney would put out a soundtrack to this film, as they've now done with many of their other animated classics.Anyway, if you haven't already seen this true Disney classic, you need to do so sometime in the near future.  After watching it, you'll realize exactly what I mean when I say that the studio has forgotten its roots, what with all the crap they're putting out today.  "Di$ney" certainly isn't Walt anymore, and it's not very magical now either.

reviewText: The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad is one hour and seven minutes long and was released in theaters on October 5, 1949. This was Disney eleventh animated film and the last of the six package films. Starting with Cinderella in 1950 Disney Studios would return to full length features again. The movie is a combination of two stories. First is the Wind in the Willows narrated by Basil Rathbone. The Wind in the Willows tells the story of J. Thaddeus Toad who is the Lord of Toad Hall. Mr. Toad is a happy-go-lucky, reckless, and careless about financial responsibilities. He has built up quite a large some of debt indulging in his hobbies and having disregarding other people properties. One day riding on his horse Cyril Proudbottom, he spots a motor car and right away he wants one. On his arrival home he shows off his new car to his friends Ratty (Water Rat), Moley (Mole) and Angus MacBadger. He is arrested at his manor and put on trial for car theft. At Mr. Toad's trial, the tavern keeper, Mr. Winkie, delivers false testimony that Mr. Toad try to sell him a stolen car. Mr. Toad is thrown in prison. It is Christmas and Cyril visits him disguised as his grandmother. Cyril helps Mr. Toad escapes from prison and Mr. Toad makes his way over to his friends home. It is there we learn that Mr. Winkie does have a deed to Toad Hall and Mr. Toad was right about the trade. Mr. Toad, Ratty, Moley, and Angus sneak back into Toad Hall and steal the deed from Mr. Winkie and Mr. Toad is found innocence of his crime. Toad Hall is now in the ownership of Mr. Toad once again. In the end Mr. Toad is back to reckless life once again.In the second story The Legend of Sleepy Hollow, Bing Crosby does the narration and provides all the voices. Ichabod Crane is the new schoolmaster of Sleepy Hollow who is very tall and gangly and lankly looking. Ichabod falls in love with Katrina Van Tassel who is the only child of wealthy farm owner Baltus Van Tassel. This makes Brom Bones very jealous and tries to break up Ichabod and Katrina. Finally on Halloween Brom gets his chance to get rid of Ichabod. At the yearly Halloween party given by Baltus Van Tassel, Brom tells the story of the Headless Horseman. This story frightens Ichabod very much. It is told that the Headless Horseman comes out at night looking for a new head and the only way to defeat him is to cross the bridge that is at the town entrance and once on the other side you are safe. Ichabod begins the slow ride home on his horse and begins to get frighten of the night. He begins to hear and see things that make him believe he is being followed by the Headless Horseman. Soon the Headless Horseman shows up and the chase is on to get to the other side of the bridge. Once on the other side Ichabod think he is safe, but the Headless Horseman throws a fiery Jack-o-lantern across the bridge. The next day the townsfolk find Ichabod Crane's hat and a smashed pumpkin but Ichabod Crane is nowhere to be found. Brom Bones marries Katrina Van Tassel.Both short films are very good to watch but you do miss Disney full length features animation movies. reviewText: Disney's THE ADVENTURES OF ICHABOD AND MR. TOAD is one of the best Halloween DVDs available, especially if you are looking for something to entertain--and spook!--the entire family.There are actually two stories on this film, the first segment being a "telling" of Kenneth Grahame's THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS.  The animation is well done--as are most Disney cartoons from this era (c. 1949)--and the narration by Basil Rathbone is wonderfully literate.  Voice characterizations are done by other actors, however, which detracts from the film's premise that the story is being "told" by the venerable Mr. Rathbone.  While this segment is certainly entertaining enough, it is NOT the highlight of the DVD.  That honor goes to the other segment....The remainder of the film is a "telling" of Washington Irving's THE LEGEND OF SLEEPY HOLLOW, and it is sheer delight.  This classic American ghost story is narrated by Bing Crosby, who also sings all of the songs and voices nearly all of the characterizations.  The script is very loyal to the source material, even including--though a little less subtly than Mr. Irving--the same wry sense of humor.  The depiction of the Headless Hessian himself is really spooky, too, though still gentle enough so as not to scare the little ones too much.  Lots of fun for old and young alike, this, and a great film for the family to watch on Halloween night!Also included on the DVD is the classic Disney animated short LONESOME GHOSTS.  This one has Mickey, Donald, and Goofy working as ghost exterminators, and one could easily make the argument that it was the inspiration for 1984's live-action GHOSTBUSTERS.  (Indeed, one of our animated heroes even utters the line "I ain't afraid of no ghosts!")  A real hoot, and another great film to include in the family's Halloween celebration.If you're already a fan of the animated THE LEGEND OF SLEEPY HOLLOW, you'll definitely want to include this DVD in your collection.  The colors are much richer than on the VHS release, and the details are understandably crisper.  You'll see Ichabod, Bram Bones, that little coquette Katrina, and the infamous Headless Horseman like you've never seen 'em before!
summary: "You Can't Reason with a Headless Man!"

reviewText: Ordinarily I want to review movies based on their own merits, but this is one that I simply cannot do that with, for two reasons.Perhaps most obviously, this isn't a regular full-length animated feature, but a "twofer", made at a time when the Disney company was making a comeback after World War II.  I am not aware of exactly when after the war that production began on this film, but they weren't in the black until 1947, a mere two years before this film's release.  That isn't that long to have worked on this, and while it has its good points (even very good points at times), it shows that they didn't spend as much time on this as they did on, say, "Bambi" (which was originally going to be the second animated feature released, so that they must have worked on it some five years!).  But precisely because of this, I want to be charitable and understanding--I can't exactly expect greatness given the circumstances.  They probably weren't equipped to make greatness at this time.Having said that, however, there is another reason, and this kind of counters the above and gives the movie points off from what I might have given it otherwise, especially given the above.  This reason is based on two facts:1) the predominant of the two stories told here is the first one told in it (meaning that the two don't really get equal time--in fact, Bing Crosby seems to tell us the "Legend of Sleepy Hollow" story through narration and song, with some animation backing it up);2) that first story, the predominant story with only one song and actual voice actors, was based on "The Wind in the Willows" by Kenneth Grahame.I have reviewed "The Wind in the Willows" book on here, and I am simply humbled by that book--the experience is almost like reading Scripture.  The book practically is its own review, and I lack the gift for words to say much of anything more that Mr. Grahame didn't already say.  Given that, this Disney treatment is a come-down, and not for reasons you might think I'm going to say--at best, it makes me wonder why they didn't wait and do a proper treatment once they could afford to risk a box-office failure.********SPOILER ALERT********I won't complain about the fact that everything was cut out except the Mr. Toad chapters (even though they keep the title "The Wind in the Willows" and we now have no idea why it's called that)--given the medium, that's probably to be expected.  This is a twofer, and the Mr. Toad chapters provide the closest thing plot-wise to connective tissue in the book, although the themes are more important in the book than the plot (indeed, Disney cut out perhaps the most significant chapter, "The Piper at the Gates of Dawn").  I suppose their disappointments with the box-office failures of Pinocchio, Fantasia, and Bambi also made them less inclined to try to capture that feeling of "calling", even though I have little doubt that they could have come close given what they accomplished with some of those.I won't complain about the fact that what was left in was changed--aside from the fact that Disney is notorious for change, I believe it's okay and even good for filmmakers adapting books to give their own take, as long as the author's intent is respected (unless that intent is just plain bad, but then why adapt the book at all?).  If they tried to recreate the book, it would come across as phony: Walt Disney is not Kenneth Grahame, and that's a good thing.  Indeed, they added an interesting thread to the book: here, instead of Mr. Toad actually making off with someone else's car (even if it is more of an addiction than grand theft auto), and the weasels invading and conquering Toad Hall with him gone (a la Penelope's suitors in "The Odyssey"), and Mr. Toad having to fight them off in order to take back his home--instead, Disney tied this all together.  Here, Mr. Toad (never one to do anything small) actually gives the weasels the deed to Toad Hall in exchange for their motorcar, so that the whole thing is legal--on his part, but he doesn't realize that the weasels stole the car, and so in actuality he now does not own the car legally.  Consequently it isn't just about taking back Toad Hall but about taking back the deed in order to prove that Mr. Toad did not steal the car.  Indeed, this arguably fixes one problem in the book: even though Mr. Toad really did take the car and escaped prison, this thread doesn't seem to be addressed again.  So that's a point in the film's favor (although combined with my real complaint, even this is arguably problematic).Even a new character that they introduced ties all this together: Cyril Proudbottom, the Cockney horse.  His closest equivalent in the book is Alfred, the Eeyore-like horse pulling Mr. Toad's gypsy cart at the beginning, but other than pulling the cart and being a horse, Cyril is a different character entirely.  What's more Cyril's role is increased vis-a-vis Alfred: he testifies on Mr. Toad's behalf at court, and then he also takes on the role of the jailer's daughter and her aunt in providing Mr. Toad with a disguise by which he can escape from prison.  I won't complain about him either, especially since he seems to be a lower class version of Mr. Toad.There are even two things that might be complaint worthy but about which I won't complain: first, the film gives the story a villain where the book didn't really have one or need one (Mr. Winkie, the bartender).  Indeed, all this guy does (other than look obnoxious with his toothy grin under a Snidely Whiplash mustache and eyes that are never more than half open--how do you NOT know he's going to be the villain?) is commit perjury by claiming that Mr. Toad tried to sell him a stolen motorcar.  Arguably that's a flaw (or at least unnecessary) but I won't complain about that.Second, while I can't expect Americans in the days before the Internet to have known as much about English ways as the English themselves (and while I am an American myself who has never been to England and don't know any English people firsthand), I think I'm getting a feel for the difference between genuine Englishness and stereotypes by Americans, and this is definitely in the latter category.  For example, instead of the Water Rat enjoying the peaceful river in the English countryside and lamenting how crowded it's getting now, and "simply messing about in boats", this book opens with Mr. Mole (not purposely but because it's a lamentable fault of his) committing what for English stereotypes is the cardinal sin: being late for tea.  Likewise, the Water Rat (who looks more like a real rat, not a water vole, and sports a Sherlock Holmes hat and pipe) says things are "dashed quiet as usual".  Surely they could have done better than this, by doing research and taking the trouble to care, especially since the book, at least, was available to them?  They almost might as well have tried to Americanize the characters, as they did with most of the Hundred Acre Wood denizens in "The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh"--it would have felt more true to life.  As I said, Walt Disney is not Kenneth Grahame, and that's okay, even good.But again, I won't complain about either of those.  Honestly, I think the biggest problem is the end of the Mr. Toad story here: I think Basil Rathbone, the narrator, misses the whole point of the story (as do the animators) by how they chose to end it--and worse, I think this ending has been copied multiple times in later adaptations (including, sadly, the Cosgrove Hall stop-motion animated movie, which is otherwise excellent--and apparently the William Horwood book sequel "The Willows in Winter").  Mr. Toad doesn't reform himself at all, but simply takes up a new fad: airplanes (which were five years old in 1908).  And worse, Basil Rathbone says of Mr. Toad, "but really, don't we envy him a bit?  I know I do."  From the book, it's clear that Mr. Toad is an addict who desperately needed his friends' intervention to save him from himself--look at all the trouble he got into because his addiction made him so stubborn-willed that he rejected his friends!  Is that someone to envy?  Really?  Supposing Mr. Toad were a drug addict, and his friends tried to wean him off his drug of choice, and he rejected this and ended up in jail, having to escape in women's clothing, and then having to fight to reclaim his home because brigands moved in, and after all this the film adaptation ended with him discovering yet a new drug, and the narrator said what Mr. Rathbone says here--would that ever fly?  I hope not!  (Though sadly, it might in this day and age--but at the time I sure hope not!)So that is easily the biggest let-down of this film treatment, and while the rest isn't so bad on its own, combined together especially with this completely missing the point contributes to my displeasure, especially since this is the company that made Bambi--I know they could have done justice to the book if they'd wanted to, especially since Walt Disney was still alive at this time.  At the very least, I could say they'd made an effort.  The most I can say here is that perhaps they felt it was beyond them and so they didn't bother trying--and while I can understand that, I don't think that's an excuse for the ending we got, as this combined with the rest makes it look like there was too little where they did try.  I wonder what a feature-length version of "The Wind in the Willows" by Disney would have looked like--as they apparently began production before World War II and had to put it on hold.Mostly to avoid more than one spoiler alert, I'll also say that they seem to have gotten the point of the "Legend of Sleepy Hollow" story wrong too, and especially given that this is an American story and Americans made this film I'm not sure I understand why.  I admit it's a long time since I read the Washington Irving story, but I was under the impression that our sympathies are supposed to lie with Brom Bones, the simple country bumpkin whom society dictates can never be with the rich lady Katrina Van Tassel--not with the funny-looking, "cultured" Ichabod Crane (who is greedy, doesn't really love Katrina, and makes exceptions to "spare the rod and spoil the child" if the child's mother is a good cook--nor is that done away with in this film).  And so the one chink in Ichabod Crane's armor, not being his looks, is his superstitious nature.  Likewise, while they don't say outright in the story, the impression we're left with is that the "Headless Horseman" that Ichabod Crane encounters is Brom Bones in disguise, who probably just scared him away from Sleepy Hollow rather than doing the pedagogue any harm.  While this route would mean doing away with the excellent forest scene (see below), the inversion of this makes it look here as though the bad guy won--Brom marries Katrina.  Shouldn't we be cheering that?  So why aren't we?  Why is the original not a very American story just by itself--why did they so feel the need to invert it here, especially given when this film came out?********END SPOILER ALERT********But that isn't all--aside from the obvious fact that they put the Mr. Toad story first despite naming Mr. Toad second in the title, look at how they chose to end the entire movie: not only does the Ichabod part hardly count as an animated adaptation rather than a retelling of the story (with songs) set to animation, but look at how that story ends.  Why would anyone want to come to a movie that ends this way when World War II was a mere four years in the past and the Cold War had begun (indeed, this was the year that Communists took over China!)?!  And it's even worse given the ending to the original Washington Irving story.  All this makes me wonder why they bothered making this film the way they did and at the time they did.  Even desperation to make a buck doesn't seem to fly, as I'd think they could have better accomplished that if they'd done it differently, in several cases leaving the original alone (especially "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow").To end on a high note, however, there is some definite good to be found here.  I wouldn't have minded "Merrily On Our Way to Nowhere in Particular" as a song so much if it weren't like "Hakuna Matata": a catchy song that runs contrary to what should be the point of the story.  Perhaps the fact that you hardly hear references to it in the media is a good thing.  And I wouldn't have minded the songs in the "Legend of Sleepy Hollow" part so much if they had been songs in a musical rather than Bing Crosby singing--although I found them unmemorable except for the "Headless Horseman" song.  There, I have to give credit where credit is due: simultaneously that is a bouncing, catchy song and a genuinely frightening warning song.  That is NOT easy to do, and I can't fault Disney for that even if I wanted to!Likewise, how they manage to tell the story through images and sound, not just through dialogue or telegraphing to the audience what's happening.  Just look at how we find out about Mr. Toad's arrest, the end of his trial, his prospects of escape from prison, and his near drowning, for example.  And the Headless Horseman sequence is excellent as well (again, it somehow manages to be hilarious and frightening at the same time, and I personally don't think the humor stands in the way of the fear factor, which it easily could have done), except for what it does to the ending.  With only that one exception, this is one of the great sequences in animation history, I'd say--but perhaps it would have been better to make that a short on its own.I don't want to throw out the baby with the bathwater, but there's a lot of dirt in the bathwater and the baby's very small here.  It doesn't really help matters much that Disney formula began to set in after this, as this was the last "package film" before Disney released proper features again starting with "Cinderella".  I won't say "don't waste your money on this", but I will say this: read the originals, especially "The Wind in the Willows", and if you decide to see this first (so that you won't feel as let down by the film after reading the book), try to forget the movie as you read.  That is, don't make this the standard by which you measure the book--let it be the other way around, if anything.God bless you all.
summary: Trying to be charitable, and has good parts, but overall not very good

reviewText: Out of all the package films of the 1940s, I consider this the best and also the worst, based on the two segments. The one that DOES work is "The Wind in the Willows". Mr. Toad as well as the other characters are exciting and fun, and there is more story and excitement to this. Basil Rathbone does a very good job narrating. The Merrily Merrily song is very delightful to hear. It's just a really good cartoon short. The one that DOESN'T work is "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow." Good god, is it boring! The setting is boring, the characters don't talk and are boring, Bing Cosby does a lousy job narrating it, and unlike "Wind in the Willows", there's no happy ending, just something mythical and confusing. Even the Headless Horseman sequence is bland and, you guessed it, boring. It's just supposed to be scary; infact I don't think it's really that scary. What do these two stories have to do with each other? The title doesn't help. The "The Adventures of" part has been used too many times. I learned this was supposed to be called "Those Two Fabulous Characters." That's really a shame because I think that would have made better sense of a title, since that's what the narrators talk about. Disney was so close with "Wind in the Willows" and yet so far with "Legend of Sleepy Hollow"! Unless Disney can find a good connection between these two stories, I would say they are DEFINITELY better off separate.

reviewText: I too vaguely remember watching the Ichabod half of this feature when I was a kid in the early 1970's.  It's been so long, this time around I can still say that first impressions are everything.  Transferring a movie to DVD and leaving reel marks and scratches is pretty unusual for Disney, but maybe they thought it would remind us that we're watching something that's more than 50 years old.  Of course, that's like a chef leaving out the seasonings and hoping we won't notice.  The original animation itself is somewhat crude for Disney, kind of in the style of Looney Tunes, but it doesn't detract from the entertainment value.Both of these stories are slow to build, but pay off nicely.  I wasn't familiar with Mr. Toad (other than the ride at Disneyland), and the themes of loss and redemption are surprisingly affecting.  Visually, everything about it is cute, and the animators have a ball with Warner Bros. style action scenes where pretty much everything onscreen flies in your face.  Both stories present an early form of 3-D energy.  The Ichabod retelling is fun and even has some spooky moments, but it's an early-nineteenth century tale steeped in late 1940's visual style and swing music.  The songs may have been influenced by  Bing Crosby's participation, but I find it odd that he was chosen over Basil Rathbone, with his horror pedigree, for the supernatural story.  We can only guess what might have been if they were switched.It'll be interesting to see if Disney gives this release the more loving treatment it deserves next time around on Blu-Ray.  The "Lonesome Ghosts" cartoon featuring Mickey, Donald and Pluto is the only one of the extras worth having, but it's in dire need of restoration.

reviewText: There is a large collection of Christmas specials out there, but the other holidays seem to get less representation.  When I was young, the Wonderful World of Disney would break out the talking magic mirror every Halloween and treat us to "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow."  It is a truly spooky cartoon with Bing Crosby's excellent narration and singing.  The character's are cleverly designed, from the lean as a rake Ichabod Crane, the lovely cocotte Katrina, and the lantern jawed Brom Van Brunt.  The fearsome Headless Horseman is the true star of the show."The Wind in the Willows" is a nice journey down a familiar path.  It too has a dark tone and slides in nicely next to the Headless Horseman.  Basil Rathbone supplies delightful narration, and Mr. Toad follows the advice of Oscar Wilde.  "The best way to fight temptation is to yield to it."  I also quite enjoy  the capacious Scottish Badger, the Holmesian Rat and loveable Mole.It is nice that Disney continued to Halloween flair with the inclusion of "Lonesome Ghosts."  Disney has an incredible backlog of great cartoons, and it is nice to see them stick a few on their DVD releases as extras.  More please.
